curriculum_alignment.nerdc_description: Hardware components, I/O devices, operating systems, software types

learning_objectives: Identify main hardware components (CPU, memory, storage, peripherals)
Differentiate input and output devices with examples
Explain operating system functions and types
Distinguish system software vs application software
Relate hardware/software choices to Nigerian computing contexts (PCs, mobiles, labs)
prerequisites: Basic idea of what a computer does
Simple binary understanding helpful but not required

content_sections.title: Computer Hardware: Core Components
content_sections.content:
**Hardware** = physical parts. Key components: 
- **CPU** (processor): ALU (arithmetic/logic), CU (control unit), registers; clock speed (GHz), cores. 
- **Memory**: **RAM** (volatile, working space), **ROM** (non-volatile firmware). 
- **Storage**: HDD/SSD, flash drives; capacity (GB/TB). 
- **Motherboard**: buses, chipset, ports. 
- **Power supply**, cooling (fan/heat sink). 

**Nigerian context**: Labs may use low-power PCs; SSDs improve speed when power is unstable.

content_sections.title: Input and Output Devices
content_sections.content:
**Input**: keyboard, mouse, touchscreen, scanner, microphone, camera, biometric readers (used in Nigerian exams/banking), barcode/QR readers, sensors (IoT). 
**Output**: monitor (LCD/LED), printer (inkjet/laser), speakers, projector, plotter. 
**I/O**: network cards, USB, storage devices (flash drives popular for file transfer in schools).

content_sections.title: Operating Systems
content_sections.content:
**OS functions**: manages hardware, provides user interface, file system, process management, memory management, device drivers, security. 
**Types**: single-user vs multi-user, single-task vs multi-task, desktop (Windows, macOS, Linux), mobile (Android, iOS), server OS. 
**Interfaces**: GUI vs CLI. 

**Nigerian context**: Many schools use Windows; phones mostly Android; Linux popular for servers/cybercafes due to cost.

content_sections.title: Software Types and Categories
content_sections.content:
**System software**: OS, device drivers, utilities (antivirus, backup, disk cleanup). 
**Application software**: productivity (word processor, spreadsheet), browsers, media players, educational apps, banking apps (mobile money). 
**Licensing**: proprietary, open-source, freeware, shareware. 

**Nigerian context**: Offline-first apps useful where internet is limited; open-source reduces cost for schools.

worked_examples.title: Choosing Storage for a School Lab
worked_examples.context: Lab PCs run slowly with old HDDs.
worked_examples.solution: Replace HDDs with SSDs for faster boot/app load; keep HDD as secondary if large storage needed. SSD benefits under frequent power cycles common in labs with limited power backup.

worked_examples.title: Classifying Devices
worked_examples.context: Items: printer, keyboard, projector, scanner, flash drive.
worked_examples.solution: Printer-output; keyboard-input; projector-output; scanner-input; flash drive-storage (also I/O).

worked_examples.title: OS Role in File Management
worked_examples.solution: File system organization, storage allocation, access permissions, UI for browse/save dialog. OS mediates between app and disk using drivers.

practice_problems.problem: Give one input and one output device.

practice_problems.answer: Process management, memory management, file system, device control, security (any two).

practice_problems.problem: Differentiate system software and application software.
practice_problems.answer: System runs/manages hardware (OS, drivers); application helps user tasks (Word, browser).
Drivers let OS communicate with specific hardware devices.

practice_problems.problem: Suggest two reasons to choose Linux for a school server in Nigeria.
practice_problems.answer: Lower licensing cost; stability; security; runs on modest hardware; good for networking and web services.

practice_problems.problem: Compare HDD vs SSD for reliability under frequent power cuts.
practice_problems.answer: SSDs have no moving parts, better shock tolerance; HDDs risk head crashes; SSD writes can corrupt if power loss mid-writeâ€”use surge/UPS; overall SSDs faster and often more resilient.

practice_problems.problem: Name one mobile OS and one desktop OS common in Nigeria.
practice_problems.answer: Mobile: Android; Desktop: Windows (others: iOS/macOS, Linux).

practice_problems.problem: Explain why RAM size affects multitasking.
practice_problems.answer: More RAM allows more programs/data in fast memory, reducing swapping to slower disk; improves multitasking responsiveness.

glossary.definition: Volatile main memory used for active programs.
Solid-state drive for persistent storage with flash memory.
Core software managing hardware and providing services to applications.

quick_checks: Give one example of system software.

exam_style_questions.question: Explain three functions of an operating system and illustrate each with a user action on a PC.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Process (runs apps), memory (allocates RAM when opening document), file system (saving file), device control (printing), UI (GUI interaction).

exam_style_questions.question: Compare HDD and SSD for a school environment in terms of speed, durability, cost, and power conditions.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: SSD faster/less fragile; HDD cheaper per GB; power cuts affect HDD heads; SSD may need UPS for safe writes; recommend SSD for performance if budget allows.
